answer: Well, I think you just jinxed it, Piers, because unfortunately the weather is set to change and there are predictions we will have a few showers on Friday, but it's April and Britain is known for having April showers.
question: What's happened?

answer: I mean it is tangible.
question: How does it feeling to you?

answer: ICHOLL: Yes.
question: Is this true?

answer: Well, it's true that not everyone wishes the happy couple, you know, a very peaceful day.
question: What have we heard about this?

answer: Well, obviously there's been a massive security operation in London and good security is invisible security.
question: What kind of preparations has there been security wise for this event?

answer: I've played them.
question: How do you feel about that?

answer: Well, I think this is Britain at its greatest, at its best.
question: Why is this such a huge event do you think?

answer: I did.
question: Did you ever meet Diana?

answer: She was really normal.
question: And what was she like?

answer: And America in particular is going crazy.
question: I mean they're kind of looking around saying, all this countries want to know about our -- you know, our royal wedding and think it's a huge thing?

answer: I think Kate -- I've never met her, of course.
question: What do you think of Kate Middleton?

answer: I can't even imagine.
question: Can you even begin to imagine what it's like at the level that Kate Middleton is about to face?

answer: Well, I think --
question: What advice would you give to the royal couple about marriage?

answer: I have definitely cracked it.
question: You've (INAUDIBLE) it out?

answer: I get so proud.
question: When you come back to London, what do you feel when you come back and it's all exciting like this and there's this huge event?

answer: Yes.
question: Are you really?

answer: Well, I don't think she's going to go for the huge big poofy thing that the Emanuels did for Diana.
question: The dress?

answer: I think she will wear some of the Queen's jewelry.
question: Jewelry?

answer: Well, have the tiara and something floral in.
question: And do what?

answer: Just delicately.
question: Really?

answer: EYMOUR: Gosh.
question: What do you imagine he might want to say?

answer: I was.
question: Were you?

answer: I believe in the monarchy when it's done properly.
question: Do you believe in the monarchy?

answer: I'll be right here, right next to you actually.
question: And where will you be on big day?

answer: It's going to be so exciting.
question: I mean it will be exciting, won't it?

answer: They are the royal --
question: How are you feeling about me being here with Anderson Cooper, Cat Deeley and Richard Quest, the royal wedding A-team?

answer: No.
question: You panicking?

answer: It is.
question: And this is almost like our little club here, isn't it?

answer: It really does.
question: Elizabeth, this must bring back so many memories for you, doesn't it?

answer: Absolutely no idea.
question: Have you any idea who has designed this dress?

answer: Well, I'm sure it's not going to look anything like Diana's dress because that was really such an '80s kind of a look.
question: Is that the kind of feeling you're getting?

answer: Jane was surmising it may be a combination of tiara and flowers.
question: But I'm sure there'll be some fashion twists, something unexpected, you know?

answer: Well, David and I at the time, we'd just left college, really, been out about a year.
question: When you designed Diana's dress -- obviously, it was one of the world's most legendary dresses -- what kind of pressure did you feel as that designer?

answer: I think she just liked us.
question: Why did Diana choose you, do you think?

answer: No, she never seemed to be under pressure.
question: Was Diana under -- I mean, obviously under huge pressure at the time, but did she show it to you when you were having all the fittings and stuff?

answer: I think it's the whole build-up, actually.
question: Is that the most pressurized moment for you?

answer: Oh, I think I would have loved to have done it.
question: Would you have liked to have made Kate's dress, or is once in a lifetime enough for this kind of thing?

answer: Well, first of all, you're going to see millions of copies of the dress everywhere.
question: I mean, what will happen to the designer of Kate Middleton's dress, do you think?

answer: Oh, there must be lots and lots.
question: Do you know how many brides got married in similar dresses to Diana's?

answer: I am.
question: Are you excited about the wedding?

answer: Oh, I'm sure she would have really liked her.
question: What would she have made of Kate Middleton, do you think?

answer: MANUEL: Well, I don't know if that happened in the past, but Dave and I decided we would have a back-up and just in case anybody worked out what it was going to look like, we made another dress, different design, and it was hanging there all ready to go.
question: If it gets snagged on the way out, do you have a spare dress?

answer: And yet nobody has a clue what it is.
question: Really?

answer: Well, you know, after we got back to the studio and we were feeling a little bit deflated -- it had been such an amazing day, and it was all quiet.
question: What did she say to you when she got a chance to talk to you again?

answer: Well, we did, but then, you know, Dave and I split and we didn't have the business anymore.
question: Did you stay in touch with her over the years?

answer: No.
question: Could you sleep the night before?

answer: Nothing went wrong.
question: Did anything go wrong on the day?

answer: Oh, I would imagine, you know, if it's all handled properly, a lot of money.
question: I mean, can you put a figure on what this might be worth to a designer in the modern day now?

answer: No.
question: And if you were a betting woman -- are you a betting woman?

answer: Well, everybody says it's Sarah Burton (ph).
question: If you were, given all the speculation about all the designers -- you know all these people -- who would you have your money on?

answer: It was absolutely fantastic.
question: What was it like?

answer: Absolutely normal.
question: ... were they resolutely normal?

answer: Oh, traditional favorites, roast chicken, crispy roast potatoes, sausages and mash, and all the traditional English puddings.
question: Prince William -- what did he like and didn't like as a boy?

answer: I think probably the milk chocolate ones he enjoyed.
question: Milk chocolate?

answer: No, not really.
question: Do you stay in touch with the royal family?

answer: No.
question: Is that true?

answer: I'm sure William follows in his footsteps, and I'm sure he's very keen on that.
question: Do you think he'll be cracking the whip with his son, saying, Right, it's got to be healthy organic food?

answer: When he was younger, when he was a little boy, he enjoyed it.
question: Is there any evidence he can cook?

answer: Yes.
question: And did you?

answer: Oh, some chicken dishes and a couple of sweet things, as well, I think.
question: What did you teach him?

answer: Possibly.
question: Is he that kind of guy?

answer: That's one of the things he enjoys.
question: Is that true?

answer: It could be.
question: Is that his, like, royal signature dish?

answer: OBB: I think it is.
question: What was it -- when you were working for the royal family, is it a strange experience compared to a normal job, I mean, or would you get very quickly used to it?

answer: I think they were as normal as it was possible for them to be.
question: Can they be normal, the royals?

answer: Initially, I did.
question: Did you feel huge pressure when you prepared food?

answer: The details of it -- it was all such a terrifying experience, I can't remember the details.
question: What was it?

answer: It had.
question: Had it all been eaten?

answer: She was absolutely incredible.
question: What kind of lady was she?

answer: She was wonderful.
question: What did you ask her?

answer: Yes, on a few occasions.
question: Did you ever cook at the palace?

answer: It was, yes, because our environment was very homely and quite intimate, the kitchens we had at Kensington Palace and Highgrove.
question: Is it intimidating to be in there and have to prepare meals?

answer: I'll be at home with my family.
question: What are you doing on Friday?

answer: Well, I'm working on a book at the moment, which is a food memoir, which is really my journey through the years and my food experiences growing up in South Africa.
question: What is The Royal Touch?

answer: Yes.
question: Like his lamb, William did?

answer: No, exactly.
question: And you can't really go wrong with that, can you?

answer: Anytime.
question: And presumably, if she wants to, she can call you for some advice, can she, Kate?
